Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Small: Toward Verifying Smart-Health Infrastructure Safety from their Impact on Human Physiology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, investigating formal modeling and analysis of medical device control operations to verify patient safety, aims to advance the state-of-the-art in guaranteeing patient safety impacted by Smart Health Infrastructure (SHI). Medical devices and their networks directly interact with human physiology and often control physiological parameters. As such, any failure in medical device control systems can cause abnormal physiological conditions resulting in health hazards and patient injury.

The physiological parameters controlled by medical devices are usually governed by complex physical processes and often vary over both space and time. For example, the concentration in blood of a drug administered by an infusion pump is governed by the drug diffusion process and varies with time and distance from the site of infusion. Further, the physical processes themselves are time-variant processes, e.g. the diffusion process changes with time depending on the past history of infusion. Any formal method should characterize the time-variant processes and spatio-temporal variations to analyze the impact of the control operations in medical devices on human physiology. This renders traditional formal methods, such as hybrid automata, inapplicable for patient safety verification. The problem gets exacerbated when two or more medical devices operate simultaneously, exhibiting aggregate effects of their individual control operations. Composition of formal models for individual medical device has to characterize the aggregate effects, which themselves can vary over space and time. To address all these challenges, the PI proposes the development of Spatio-Temporal Hybrid Automata (STHA), that migrates from the conventional perspective of temporal event based state transition to a spatio-temporal perspective where state transitions are instigated over both time and space.

Broader Impacts: With the increasingly aging population and a linear increase in life expectancy the need for health-care anywhere anytime is immense. Further, the cost of health-care rises exponentially when diseases are identified at a later stage. Thus, early detection of diseases can lead to better health at a lower cost. SHIs, enabling health-care anytime anywhere, and early detection of diseases require complex medical control systems to be deployed on the human body. Unsafe operation of these medical device control systems can lead to hazards within the human body. Increasing cases of such hazards leads to decreased social acceptance of these devices. Further, it also leads to stricter compliance rules on these devices from regulatory agencies such as FDA. A methodology for providing guarantees on safety of a medical device control system will make a stronger case for their reliable operation. This will help the regulatory agencies to perform a better evaluation of the device and will lead to increased social acceptance. The PI also has a history of employing underrepresented populations, particularly women and Hispanics, at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent advances in the capabilities of medical sensors and devices, as well as form factors, have made it possible for these technologies to be worn on or implanted in the human body. That progress along with technological advances in wireless mobile devices, smart phones, the Internet-of-Things (IoT) and cloud-based services has made plausible the vision of Smart Health Infrastructure (SHI) that can provide automated health care anytime and anywhere. 

But operational failure of any of the SHI components can directly or indirectly lead to health hazards; especially because a major portion of SHI — specifically the medical devices and their networks, in which the medical devices can coordinate operations with each other — are in direct contact with the human body, often controlling (and thus directly impacting) an individual’s physiology.

In addition, in the presence of a network of devices the effect of each device may result in aggregate behavior that cannot be modeled by a simple combination of the individual effects of each device (Figure 1). The research carried out in this project has enabled theoretical assurance of patient safety in the use of SHIs in general, and specifically in regard to medical devices in presence of aggregate behavior. This has helped to increase public confidence in the performance of SHIs and boost their acceptance by society.

SHIs are typically validated through clinical studies, which are expensive and may even cause harm to the human body. Due to the Institutional Review Board’s complex approval process, subject recruitment and protocol execution process, clinical studies also take a long time to complete. Hence, it is nearly impossible to conduct experiments to test a large set of configurations of an SHI.

In this project, conducted in the IMPACT Lab (http://impact.asu.edu), Arizona State University, Dr. Sandeep Gupta and his group of researchers have developed a framework that can reduce the set of clinical studies required to assure the safety of SHIs. The core idea of Spatio-Temporal Hybrid Automata (STHA) enables evaluation of different SHI configurations through theoretical proofs, thus making it unnecessary to do clinical studies on a subset of configurations. This can significantly reduce the number of clinical studies needed to assure safety of an SHI and thus reduces the cost and  provides more time for marketing the device.

In this research, Dr. Gupta’s team has collaborated with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to conduct STHA-based analysis on medical devices such as an artificial pancreas. A major outcome of this project is the development of a usable SHI development tool called Health-Dev (Figure 2) that requires the SHI manufacturer to specify the architecture of SHI using a simple user interface.

The tool also allows the manufacturer to specify models of the intended operation of the SHI in the form of any popular modeling techniques such as state-based models or hybrid systems or STHA. The tool then automatically generates test cases and executes the models to confirm the safety of different configurations of the system. It also generates sensor and actuator interface codes that are based on configurations proven to be safe. Usage of the safety-assured code in the SHI design can also provide evidence of safety and can be used by regulatory agencies such as FDA to assess the safety of the SHI.

STHA is a fundamental improvement from the one-dimensional hybrid automata because the STHA can factor in space as well as time to its analysis. This is especially useful for analyzing medical devices that interact with the human body, since any input provided by the medical device into the human body travels either through the skin or through the blood stream or through the nerves to the entire body, and can mix with other drugs to provide aggregate effects (Figure 1).

STHA is unique in its ability to mathematically model aggregate effects. It has been used to model and analyze the safety of an artificial pancreas that helps people with Type 1 diabetes to maintain appropriate insulin dosage for controlling blood glucose levels.

In collaboration with the FDA, the research team has shown that the STHA-based analysis could identify several unsafe configurations of the medical device which were not revealed by traditional hybrid automata-based techniques. Hence, the STHA can better assure the safety of an artificial pancreas. 

The STHA modeling and analysis can be applied to a large number of complex medical device applications, ranging from automatic infusion control to prosthetic arm control. A history of fatal hazards to the human body due to faulty operation of these devices has led to stricter regulations on their use. Further, assurance of the safe operation of the medical devices currently relies on expensive clinical trials that are generally limited in number and cannot cover all possible device operating conditions. This methodology can be used to expedite medical device approval process.
